content.content: Severe bleeding (hemorrhage) is the leading cause of preventable death after trauma.
An adult has approximately 5 liters of blood. Losing 1 liter (≈ 1/3 of total blood volume) can cause shock.

rows: Most severe – can exsanguinate in minutes

items: 4. Hemostatic agent (QuikClot®, Celox®, etc.) packed into wound
5. Tourniquet (only if life-threatening limb bleeding cannot be controlled by other means)

content.content:
Tourniquet Rules
• Apply 2–3 inches above wound (never over joint)
• Write time on tourniquet and patient's forehead
• Do NOT loosen or remove once applied unless by medical professional
• Only remove if evacuation will take > 6–8 hours and bleeding has stopped
Shock is inadequate perfusion of tissues and vital organs. Treat ALL critical trauma patients for shock even if signs are not yet present.

items: Elevate legs 8–12 inches (unless spine, chest, or pelvic injury suspected)
Position of comfort (or on side if unconscious and breathing)

A fracture is a broken bone. It can be fractured in-line, displaced, or angulated (visibly deformed). Fractures can also be simple or compound (bone ends protruding from the skin).

items: Patient cannot move or weight injured area
Anticipate shock with several fractures or a femur fracture
Consider pain medication (see OTC pain medication chart)

content.content:
Always pad splints adequately
Splint extremities in normal anatomical position
For shaft fractures, splint joint above and joint below
For joint fractures, splint shaft above and shaft below

Femur fractures are splinted with long, rigid materials, and subsequently "buddy splinted" for more support
Improvising a traction device is no longer an acceptable wilderness medicine practice.
Evacuate immediately

Check CSM before & after immobilization
Apply a pelvic binder
Package in a position of comfort on a litter and evacuate immediately

Dislocations occur when bones in a joint are displaced or misaligned. The dislocation can be due to a direct MOI, as with a fall, or an indirect MOI associated with an over extension of the joint's range of motion.

items: Patient cannot move limb below the dislocation
Obtain patient consent and disclose possible complications that occur with reductions (especially shoulders)
Attempt to reduce dislocation (see steps for patella, digit, and shoulder)
Consider NSAIDs for pain (see OTC pain medication chart)
If reduction is unsuccessful: Evacuate immediately

content.content: Patella Dislocation – Steps for Reducing an Indirect Patella Dislocation

items: 1. Have the patient take deep breaths and focus on completely relaxing their quadriceps muscle while in seated position or lying supine (on back).
2. Gently extend (straighten) the lower leg. The patella may reduce spontaneously.

3. If the patella has not reduced, use your other hand to apply gentle force to the outermost edge of the displaced patella, and guide the patella back to the mid line. Successful reduction may be accompanied by a perceptible "clunk."

content.content: When opposing forces on digits are too much, one or more small bones can displace or "pop out" of their normal position. The middle joint is the most common to dislocate in digits.
Steps for Reducing Indirect Digit Dislocation

items: 1. Grasping the joint above and the joint below the dislocation, apply opposing traction until a perceptible "clunk" is achieved.
2. Assess for reduction of the joint. If the joint cannot be reduced after 2 attempts, splint it and evacuate.
3. Immobilize the finger using a flat, hard surface under the digit and buddy taped to adjacent digit.

content.content:
Ask the patient if they can move or use the injured area. If they cannot, the injury is usually unstable and the patient will need a more rigid immobilization device to protect the injured area from further damage.
For example, a torn ACL will allow the knee to buckle with sudden lateral movements.

Usually the result of physical trauma such as a bone fracture or blunt/crushing force to an arm or leg, compartment syndrome results in increased pressure within one of the body's anatomical compartments.
This is a dangerous situation where a swelling muscle is constricted within the fascia that surrounds it and consequently acts as a tourniquet, cutting off blood flow to the affected area, which can result in necrosis, or death of tissue.
Use of certain unconditioned muscles can also cause an increase in blood flow causing tension to the fascia, such as in shin splints. Pain can be unbearable and is usually disproportionate to the injury. Pain is also not well controlled with mild anti-inflammatory OTC drugs like ibuprofen.
Signs and Symptoms of Acute Compartment Syndrome

items: Pain – disproportionate to the findings of a physical examination
Paresthesia – a person may complain of feeling 'pins and needles' or numbness
Paralysis – full paralysis of a limb is rare and may indicate a nerve or muscle lesion
Pallor & pulselessness – also rare and occurs in the late stages when pressure is high

content.content:
Timely surgery is necessary to alleviate pressure.
If suspected, evacuate immediately
Assess and treat wilderness-related athletic injuries.

items: 1. Define the following terms: sprain, strain and tendonitis.
2. Understand why compartment syndrome occurs with athletic injuries.
3. Assess for stability and treat common wilderness-related athletic injuries.
Demonstrate assessment skills for athletic injuries.
Apply a compression wrap to knees and ankles.
Apply slings and swathes for shoulder injuries.
Show sound judgment and good critical thinking skills when making evacuation decisions.

content.content: Spine injuries can range from sprains, strains, and minor stable fractures to major unstable fractures involving spinal cord injury with neurological deficits and/or neurogenic shock. Recognizing and differentiating between no spine injury, low risk, or high risk spine injury is an important assessment for the WFR certified rescuer to determine. Mastering the Focused Spine Assessment (FSA) is critical.
Low Risk Spinal Cord Injury – Determined from the FSA
Suspicion for spinal cord involvement is low

items: Sudden mid-line or paraspinal pain, tenderness, swelling and/or discoloration
Call for a rescue. If unavailable, assess evacuation possibilities based on time of day, terrain, environmental factors, patient injuries and available resources
Assess benefit/risk of self-evac and use extreme caution w/a self-evac
Evacuate to definitive care for further evaluation

content.content: High Risk Spinal Cord Injury – Determined from the FSA
Suspicion for spinal cord involvement is high

items: Sudden mid-line or paraspinal pain, tenderness, swelling and/or discoloration
Crepitus (grinding sound or sensation produced between fractured bones)
CSM deficits such as: numbness, tingling, hot or cold sensations, weakness, and paralysis
Weakness, numbness, or pain that travels down the arms or legs
Neutral alignment should be restored with gentle cervical traction unless met with resistance, increased pain, or new or worsening neurological deficits.
Move patient using a multi-person lift or log roll to avoid twisting the spine.
Move patient with axial movements once on a carrying device (the "W" move).
Best practice to protect the spine is with a vacuum spine board.
If unavailable, use thick, soft materials underneath patient and around head and neck to protect the spine when waiting for an evacuation or when carrying on an improvised litter.
If self-evacuating, use extreme caution as to not re-injure the spine.
Alert, awake, and reliable patients with spine injuries will usually self splint to protect their spine.

content.content:
NOTE:
Rigid C-collars can cause more injury and are no longer "best practice" in wilderness medicine.
Consider applying a soft collar with paraspinal cervical pain.
Manually holding C-spine with a combative patient can cause more injury to the spine.
Backboards used as an extrication tool should be adequately padded with thick, soft materials underneath and around the head and neck to protect and maintain the natural curvature to the spine.
Focused Spine Assessment (FSA) Checklist – based on NEXUS™ criteria

rows: Spine Tenderness or Pain (mid-line or paraspinal)?
Altered Mental Status (less than A&O x3)?
Back cold to the touch? (adapted for the field)

content.content: NOTE: If a "Yes" is present in the table above, determine if HIGH or LOW risk spine injury and protect the spine accordingly.
To assess and treat spine injuries safely.

items: 1. Assess for spine injuries via the Focused Spine Assessment.
2. Understand why the Focused Spine Assessment is done after the Secondary Assessment.
3. Differentiate between no spine injury, low risk, or high risk spine injury.
4. Understand why high cord injuries can result in neurogenic shock.
5. Understand what type of spine injury needs spine protection during an evacuation.
Log-roll a patient solo and with the help of others
Load and package a patient onto a carrying device
Sound judgment and good critical thinking skills when making evacuation decisions

content.content: Traumatic brain injuries (TBI) occur with an external force to the head or the body causing the brain to rapidly move back and forth inside of the cranium (skull), stretching and damaging brain tissue and causing chemical changes in the brain. Injured brain tissue swells (edema) and/or bleeds within the cranium. This accumulating fluid puts pressure on the brain called intracranial pressure (ICP), altering the patient's mental status and neurological functions. An isolated head injury is rarely a cause of hypotension (low BP). If hypotension is present consider hypovolemic or neurogenic shock from associated trauma. A TBI can result from a closed or open head injury.

TBIs range in severity with the most common resulting in a minor concussion called an mTBI. It is important to note that the injured brain is more sensitive to stress or further injury until it fully recovers.

items: Altered mental status – most commonly A&O x3
With or without a brief period of unresponsiveness
Nausea/vomiting (persistent vomiting is a key sign in kids)
Raccoon eyes & battle signs (late signs of a skull Fx)
If no S/Sx of an mTBI are present post MOI, awaken every 2 hours to assess for signs of an mTBI
A period of unresponsiveness post MOI warrants an evacuation
Evacuate anyone who has the S/Sx of an mTBI
If ICP presents, indicating a moderate to severe TBI, evacuate immediately
Positive pressure ventilation if RR is less than 8/min

content.content:
Increased systolic blood pressure ↑BP (widening pulse pressures)
Strong, radial pulses (bounding pulse)
↓HR Bounding and below 60 bpm
↑ICP Intracranial Pressure Increasing
↓RR Slow & Irregular Breaths below 8/min

NOTE: Cushing's Triad is the A of a TBI. Most TBIs do not result in Cushing's Triad.
SIDE NOTE: Cushing's Triad is also the A for HACE, a hemorrhagic stroke, and severe hyponatremia.

items: Leave the person flat (do not raise the legs)

content.content:
During a training session a 17 year old hits the biggest jump on a slope-style competition course. Their landing was off and they were thrown immediately onto their head. The person is unresponsive, postures (decerebrate 2x), is apneic (not breathing), and has weak, radial pulses. There is bleeding from their head, but no other signs of trauma are present. During your patient assessment you notice that they have pale skin and mucous membranes, are cool, and clammy to the touch with a thready carotid pulse of 150. Radial pulses are now absent bilaterally, you also notice a priapism and a blown right pupil.
What are the injuries?
What are the vitals showing?
What is your treatment?
Assess, treat and plan evacuations for patients with S/Sx of a TBI.

items: 1. Understand the pathophysiology behind a TBI and the associated S/Sx.
2. Assess and treat the S/Sx of a TBI.
3. Differentiate between vitals presenting a TBI vs. shock.
Demonstrate sound judgment and good critical thinking skills when making evacuation decisions.

content.content: The thoracic cavity is a closed system, or vacuum, which allows air to be pulled in (inspiration) and expelled (expiration) based on pressure differentials between the cavity and the atmosphere. A loss of integrity in the chest wall can result in life-threatening conditions.
Rib Fracture (One or more fractured ribs)

items: May or may not see deformity
Intercostal muscles splint the fractured rib(s)
Taping middle-front to middle-back may help pain

content.content: (Fractured segments along ribs can produce a freely floating plate of the chest wall that moves back and forth during respiration called paradoxical movement)
(A puncture wound in chest wall that allows air to be "sucked" into the thoracic cavity)

items: One or more wound(s) on chest wall

content.content: A punctured lung resulting from trauma to the thoracic cavity can happen with all chest injuries. Immediate stabilization of chest injuries can prevent a pneumothorax. The patient will exhibit respiratory distress and may need positive pressure ventilation when a pneumothorax is present.

A life-threatening condition when air is trapped in the thoracic cavity and can occur with open and closed chest injuries. Pressure prevents the good lung from expanding, affecting systemic perfusion. The patient presents with severe respiratory distress, and a weak, rapid pulse. The pressure can be relieved by removing the occlusive dressing to let the trapped air escape and then quickly re-covering the wound.
Occlusive dressings are taped on all four sides and must be monitored and burped if tension pneumothorax presents.
Assess chest trauma and treat accordingly.

items: 1. Understand the physiology of the thoracic cavity.
2. Understand the importance of finding chest injuries in the "B" portion of the primary assessment.
3. Understand the presentations and treatments for fractured ribs, a flail chest, and a sucking chest wound with associated exit wounds.
4. Explain why immediate immobilization of chest injuries can prevent complications of a pneumothorax.
5. Explain what a pneumothorax is and its complications and treatments.
Know when, and how to burp an improvised occlusive dressing.
Demonstrate sound judgment and good critical thinking skills when making evacuation decisions.

content.content: An evisceration is an open abdominal wound in which internal organs may protrude from the abdominal cavity and be exposed to the outside environment.

items: Have patient bend knees to reduce pain

content.content: A green house dressing is important to keep the organs wet and warm during a wilderness evacuation. If the organs dry out they may no longer be viable. Rescuers must also attempt to minimize loss of the patient's core temperature from the evisceration by insulating the dressing and placing the patient in a hypowrap.

items: 1. Place wet 4x4's covering all visible abdominal organs.
2. Tape plastic or non-permeable membrane on all 4 sides, covering entire wound.
3. Tape insulation on top of the dressing.

content.content: TRAUMATIC INJURIES – OTC PAIN MEDICATION CHART

Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) are excellent pain relievers when managing pain in remote settings. NSAIDs reduce pain, fever, and swelling by blocking prostaglandins. However, they can irritate the stomach and increase bleeding risk. Acetaminophen is best for kids, acetaminophen is also good and non-irritating when the patient has a history of stomach ulcers or bleeding disorders.

content.content: Recognize, treat, and evacuate all major traumatic injuries commonly seen in the wilderness setting.

items: 1. Control life-threatening bleeding and treat for shock in all critical patients.
2. Properly clean, dress, and consider delayed closure/antibiotics for contaminated wounds.
3. Splint fractures and reduce appropriate dislocations.
4. Perform a Focused Spine Assessment and protect the spine when indicated.
5. Recognize and treat moderate/severe TBI and evacuate immediately when ICP is present.
6. Stabilize chest injuries and apply occlusive/greenhouse dressings when indicated.
7. Use the OTC pain medication chart appropriately.
